Documenting sources is often&nbsp;called either <strong>citing sources</strong> or <strong>citations</strong><em>.</em><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"What it means to document your sources"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>What is an important reason for documenting your sources?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_0d347ae0-6bed-0e58-d23e-49af7b530c01\" style=\"width: 200px; Cite or name the source in the<strong> body</strong> of your work.&nbsp; This is an <strong>in-text citation</strong>.<br /><br /><strong>Part 2</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp; Provide extra detail about the citation in a list of references at the <strong>end</strong> of your work.<br /><br /><img alt=\"For example, the body of your family history might include the sentence &quot;Stefan and Anna Kuchar arrived at Ellis Island in the winter of 1898&quot; followed by Kuchar comma 2000 in parentheses.  Your list of references provides more detail about Kuchar's book in an entry that reads Kuchar, comma, M period 2000 in parentheses, period,  Kuchars, Kitchens, and Kuchan, New York, New York, Skyscraper Publishing.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p><p><br /><em>Note</em>: ONLY the sources that you cite in the body of your work go into the&nbsp;list of references at the end of your writing.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Members of your family are reading and enjoying the family history you wrote.&nbsp; Where will they see the two parts of the documentation system?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_a6595ec4-41e7-13f3-353f-f1650f7e9784\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; However, in your final written family history, you do not write about Aunt Wilma.&nbsp; Do you need to include the book about Aunt Wilma in your list of references?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_87cb2af6-075c-aa6f-12c4-56f7c389d57e\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">MC Placeholder<br /><strong>ID: mc_87cb...</strong></jumc><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>There are five reasons why it is important to document your sources:<br /><br /><strong>1.&nbsp; By crediting your sources, you acknowledge ownership of the ideas.</strong><br /><br />Using someone else&#39;s ideas is acceptable; many writers do so. To demonstrate your honesty as a writer, it is important to give credit to those whose ideas you have borrowed.<br /><br />Your cousin Magda Kuchar, who owns a popular bakery, has written a recipe book and included an introduction about how she acquired some of her best recipes.<br /><br />In her introduction she describes your&nbsp;great-grandparents&#39; arrival from Poland at Ellis Island in New York City in 1898:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"color: black; font-family: times new roman,serif; font-size: 14px; width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>Where it all began. . .</strong><br /><br />In January of 1898, Stefan and Anna Kuchar arrived at Ellis Island. They jostled with the crowd that had made its way to the upper deck.&nbsp; Stefan carried all their worldly possessions in two small cases, while Anna carried only a small box with a leather strap.&nbsp; She clutched it to herself with one hand, holding Stefan&#39;s arm with the other.&nbsp; What did this carefully protected box contain?&nbsp; It was full of Anna&#39;s cookies!&nbsp; These cookies,&nbsp;hard when dry and chewy when moistened, had sustained the young couple on their long journey.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Why documenting sources is important"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>You use some of this information when you write about your great-grandparents&#39; arrival at Ellis Island.&nbsp;&nbsp; Why do you need to give credit to Magda Kuchar?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_405e0030-dc53-e066-c0e6-da281c0f671a\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">MC Placeholder<br /><strong>ID: mc_405e...</strong></jumc><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>The paragraph from your family history with in-text citations looks like this.&nbsp; The in-text citations are indicated with highlighting:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Stefan and Anna Kuchar arrived at Ellis Island in the&nbsp;winter of 1898 <span class=\"marker\">(Kuchar, 2000)</span>.&nbsp; The story of Anna carrying only a single item off the ship--a small box of cookies--has been passed down through the generations. Those cookies were uniquely suited to travel because they were &quot;hard when dry and chewy when moistened&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(Kuchar, 2000, p. 25)</span>. The simple cookie provided the young couple with food as well as memories of home during the long voyage. The recipe still lives on in Anna&#39;s Famous Poppy Seed Cookies, available at Magda&#39;s Pastries.</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><img alt=\"\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" />&nbsp;See the mini-lesson <em>Basic rules for documenting sources</em> for information about formatting in-text citations.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1,"showRuler":1},"leftText":"<p><strong>2.&nbsp; You give your readers a chance to follow up and read more about what you have told them.</strong><br /><br />Some readers will want to learn more about the topics you wrote about.&nbsp; Documenting your sources allows them to find more information.<br /><br />Your cousin Tillie insists that your great-great-grandfather was a horse thief known as Galloping James Clifford, and you want to include information about him in your family history.&nbsp; She shares a crumbling scrap of a newspaper article with you:</p><div style=\"padding:10px; background-image:url('/images/newspaper_background1.png');background-size:cover;\"><table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"color: black; font-family: times new roman,serif; font-size: 14px; width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>Horse Thief Strikes Again</strong><br />Hannibal, MO&mdash;July 1, 1888</p><p>A third horse theft in a string of such thefts occurred last week on the Old River Road.&nbsp; Harry Lewis woke up to find both of his horses gone.&nbsp; Harry told our reporter, &quot;Those horses are long gone, and I think I know who did it!&quot;</p><p>Harry suspects the notorious horse thief, Galloping James Clifford, who has been previously linked to such thefts.&nbsp; The local sheriff promises swift punishment if Mr. Clifford is apprehended.&nbsp; Neighbors are pitching in to help Harry and his family as they struggle to maintain the farm without their two workhorses.&nbsp;</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>What is disappointing about Cousin Tillie&#39;s newspaper scrap titled &quot;Horse Thief Strikes Again&quot;?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_30c3d8e9-51dc-c998-ae8d-ca640aabf772\" style=\"width: 200px; One of the things he told you was that that family members living in New York City in the 1930s would take weekend day trips to an amusement park and beach area known as Coney Island.</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Why might you want to include more information about Coney Island from experts who are not members of your family?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_04b1bfdd-f549-47a0-1dbf-bbb758c17e2b\" style=\"width: 200px; Note that you have also included a &quot;personal communication&quot; citation for Grandpa Walsh because these are stories that he told you personally:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Grandpa Walsh told stories of bringing my mother and her brothers on weekend excursions to Coney Island in the 1930s.&nbsp; They escaped the oppressive August heat of Brooklyn for a chance to enjoy the surf as well as to ride the roller coaster and other attractions<span class=\"marker\"> (P. Walsh, personal communication, December 25, 1972)</span>.&nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">Historian Richard Cox (1979)</span> tells us, &quot;After the 1920s, when trolleys and trains linked Coney Island to the rest of the city, a vast cross-section of New Yorkers gained access to its beaches, its rides, and its hoopla.&nbsp; You avoid plagiarism.</strong><br /><br />Plagiarism is using the&nbsp;words or ideas of someone else and passing them off as your own. &nbsp; Plagiarism can be either</p><ul style=\"padding-left:15px;\"><li><strong>intentional</strong>, when you knowingly use another person&#39;s work, OR</li><li><strong>unintentional</strong>, when you do not realize that you need to give credit to sources used.&nbsp;</li></ul><p>In either case, plagiarism is a serious offense.&nbsp; They are known as<em> </em><strong>styles</strong>.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>MLA</strong>, <strong>APA</strong>, and <strong>Chicago</strong> are the most commonly used styles. This <em>Try it</em> uses APA style.</p><p>Each style has its own formatting requirements.&nbsp; For example, <strong>APA</strong> requires a date for in-text citations while <strong>MLA</strong> does not.&nbsp; Each style has a different name for the list of sources.<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-table\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\" style=\"background:F2F2F2;\">&nbsp;</th><th scope=\"col\" style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>In-text citation</strong></th><th scope=\"col\" style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>List of sources is called . . .</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>APA</strong></td><td style=\"text-align: center;\">requires date</td><td style=\"text-align: center;\">References<nobr></nobr></td></tr><tr><td><strong>MLA</strong></td><td style=\"text-align: center;\">does not require date</td><td style=\"text-align: center;\">Works Cited</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Chicago</strong></td><td style=\"text-align: center;\">uses footnotes</td><td style=\"text-align: center;\">Bibliography</td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Comparing  and choosing citation styles"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Your family history concludes with a list of References, and all of your in-text citations include a date.&nbsp;
